So I just came here to say that after paying one month of Ubisoft + just to try AC: Shadows, and after playing it for about two hours, I think the moment has come for me to bid farewell to one of my favourite franchises ever, one that has offered me great gaming experiences since 2007, but that unfortunately stopped after Origins.  That was the last AC game I really enjoyed and finished, cause even though Odyssey was really entertaining, I just didn't feel motivated enough to complete it and I think I reached a dead end where there were hundreds of side quests but I couldn't find the way to progress through the main quest... not sure if it was a glitch or something but I don't care anymore.  I tried valhalla but after two hours I stopped playing, and something similar happened with shadows.  It's not only the lack of "assassin's creed"-like things to do, the essesnce of the game is now completely lost and the more you progress, the more lame/boring/unnecessary side quests appear to try and keep you playing and playing and playing as an errand boy/girl in an infinite world, and then if you can stand the tediousness then you may eventually see the ending of the game(a cutscene or something).  More linear games with more engaging content like the first ones, black flag, Unity and even Syndicate are now in the past and unfortunately corporate decisions and money are now above art, not only in this game but in many.  I will revisit the older games at some point though, to remember those good time I had when I played them for the first time,  and hope the first one gets a remake as well tho I don't remember playing a remake of a game that surpassed the experience of what the original made me feel.  Goodbye, modern Assassin's Creed.

That's what I came into Shadows looking for, and it has delivered, just as well as Odyssey and Origins did. It is far from a perfect game, and the criticisms here are valid - dialogue is really forced and cringy at times, side quests can get repetitive, and I HATE microtransactions in single-player games. All that being said, the core game here is beyond solid.

I find it immersion breaking when shows, movies, and video games especially portray female warriors as physically strong if not stronger than the average male warriors. Surprisingly, and refreshingly I might add, that’s not the case with Naoe. I haven’t unlocked Yasuke yet so idk if it changes but so far in every instance where she gets into close combat with a male warrior she gets over powered significantly. She actually has to fight smart and use her opponents body weight against them using momentum. It is so satisfying she’s not  a 115 pound super human who can over power a 175-215 lb solid man. So yeah I’m surprised to say it but I’m enjoying it so far. I was never going to buy this game but and when I found out Yasuke couldn’t parkour I had already given up hope of even playing it. So I was bummed that Yasuke got the short end of the stick seeing as the best part of Assassins Creed is the stealth and traversal. Especially the parkour traversal. A lot of people are comparing the graphics to Ghost of Tsushima. But let’s not forget — Ghost of Tsushima was originally developed for the PS4, while Assassin’s Creed is being built straight for current-gen consoles. I used to love the AC series, but they really lost me when they dumbed down the climbing system to the point where scaling viewpoints meant just holding down two buttons.

There used to be some real gameplay challenge in those climbing puzzles, and it felt genuinely satisfying when you finally reached the top. Now? It just feels like a chore.

Black Flag was still a fantastic game, but let’s be honest — that was mostly thanks to the ship battles and pirate vibes. Then came Origins with its clunky knockoff of the Dark Souls combat system, and it only went downhill from there.

I might give Shadows a shot... once it hits the bargain bin for twenty bucks. Unless Ghost of Yotei is out by then — in which case, it’s game over.
